column4: how can i securely wipe my deleted files so they cant be recovered?
delete them, then create some huge null files from /dev/zero until the disk is full, then delete them again.
that isnt very efficent nor secure for sensitive data

it's a lot more secure that 'shredding' files ... due to the way the filesystem works, files tend to get moved around so the safest option is to fill up ALL the empty space.. (an even better option is to tar the entire filesystem to a clean new drive and then zero-wipe the old one.
what I said are the best and second-best options afaik..
how would you create the null file then
cat /dev/zero > useupspace
the file will be called 'useupspace' ; when you run out of hard drive cat will crash and you just 'rm useupspace' to get rid of the huge empty file
its a very slow process :(
yes, it is...
which is why I usually zero-wipe another drive and clone the filesystem over using tar
whats zero wipe?
erase the entire disk to factory-clean using dban or dumping /dev/zero to /dev/sda
is that practicall for a computer in constant use?
or more for the paranoid user?
it takes a little while.. if you do things right you can do the wipe and clone while the computer is still in use, and keep downtime to a minimum just swapping the drives and reparing grub.
but dont u loose all your files
how do i do the null option if my root and my home our seperate partitions?

two drives; you put in a second drive (which means the computer os down for a minute or two) then when it's up again you can zero-wipe the space drive, make a filesystem on it, tar the files over.. takes a couple of hours but the computer can still be used.. then once that's done shutdown, swap the drives around, boot a live CD and reinstall GRUB, bring the computer up, and zero-wipe the old drive..
wont tarring it over also bring the deleted files back to?
and last is zero-wipe a program or what is it
to sero wipe, become root and cat /dev/zero > /dev/sdx (where x is whatever drive you want to wipe)
